Award.AwardTitle: Real-world language: Future directions in the science of communication and the communication of science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the organization of a two-day workshop on future challenges in language science, with integrated discussion of science communication (making language science research accessible to specialist peers, scientists in other fields, and the general public). The workshop will take place in Madison, WI, immediately following the 2018 Cognitive Science Society annual meeting. Language science is an interdisciplinary area drawing on theories and methods from linguistics, cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, and artificial intelligence, among other fields. The primary goal is basic scientific understanding of the human capacity for language and potential longer-term impact on technology, education, and health.Â 

Invited speakers will 1) provide critical reviews of different theoretical perspectives, methodological approaches, and tools (such as eye tracking, electroencephalography, or functional magnetic resonance imaging); 2) focus on near- and long-term challenges facing language science; or 3) focus on science communication and education. In an effort to spark discussion and collaboration, research interest groups will be formed that will hold videoconference meetings in Fall, 2018. Plans include strategies for promoting student participation and inclusion of women and members of under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to organize two workshops related to the science of communication and the communication of science ("Real-world language: Future directions in the science of communication and the communication of science"). The first was a two-day event in June, 2018, that brought together 9 speakers, 11 panelists, and 74 additional participants. Most sessions focused on how cognitive scientists and neuroscientists can advance the science of communication, and in particular, the science of human language, with particular emphasis on how we can transcend current scientific (empirical, methodological, and computational) boundaries. Other sessions focused on science communication, with particular emphasis on how and why language scientists should and can best engage with non-specialist audiences (scientists in other areas, educators, policy makers, journalists, children, and the general public) to communicate why and how our science matters -- both for purposes of intrinsic basic research (pure discovery) and translation to technology, education, and health. All participants (speakers, other faculty, and graduate and undergraduate students) engaged in multiple brainstorming and breakout sessions where we generated ideas for transforming the science of communication and enhancing our science communication efforts. This two-day event also honored Michael Tanenhaus on the occasion of him being awarded the Rumelhart Prize from the Cognitive Science Society, the highest honor in cognitive science. 

 

The first event garnered unexpected external support from universities and a corporate sponsor, which allowed us to extend our efforts to a second, one-day event in 2019 at the University of Connecticut ("Science and imagination: Inspiring public interest in inquiry and discovery"). This event began with breakout workshops on key themes (e.g., Mike Tanenhaus led a workshop on the Vannevar Bush report, "The Endless Frontier", which makes a case for scientific research and discovery as a public good, and Julie Sedivy led a session on effective science communication), and culminated in a series of 5 talks by external and internal speakers addressing how scientists can engage the public with their passion and excitement for research and tackling myriad unsolved challenges in the neurobiology and cognitive science of language. 

 

Regarding intellectual merit, both events addressed challenges that face scientists studying human language and communication, and potential ways we can transcend current scientific boundaries. Regarding broader impacts, both events brought together faculty, postdoctoral trainees, graduate students, and undergraduate students. The 2019 event also included high school students. We mindfully designed the events to include sessions where the most junior individuals would come face-to-face for discussions with the most senior. Students reported finding the sessions inspirational, and we hope that students at various levels of development will be inspired to pursue scientific careers. We also hope that students and faculty will be inspired by these events, while also enabled by concrete recommendations for effective science communication, to engage with the public.
